desc: This popular recreation area set on the eastern slopes of the Santa Cruz Mountains offers picnic areas, a playground, playing fields, an amphitheater, and an archery range. Miles of hiking trails lead into shady canyons and forests and up to Skyline Boulevard.

website: Rancho San Antonio Open Space Preserve
place: Rancho San Antonio Open Space Preserve
desc: This huge preserve is a local favorite with hikers, bikers, and horseback riders due to its 23 miles of trails through shaded creeks, open meadows, and oak woodlands, many offering great views.
This park is full of roads once used to transport cinnabar to the reduction works. Hikers and joggers now traverse the 34 miles of trails through chaparral, oak woodlands, and grasslands.

With a backdrop of sandy cliffs, this secluded, clothing-optional beach is picturesque, clean, and peaceful, with caves to explore.

Sand and surf front the village of Capitola; its esplanade is lined with busy restaurants and boutiques that paint a scene of summer perfection.

More than 30 miles of trails in rugged forested and open terrain offer views in all directions. Steep sandstone canyons with unusual rock formations and challenging overhangs make this a rock-climbing destination.

Take a first-­class cruise through the Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary aboard the Chardonnay II—a 70-foot sailing yacht. A variety of sailing charters offer everything from whale watching to wine tasting.
This sandy beach is popular for sports such as volleyball and windsurfing.
This newest state beach is still relatively undiscovered, with beautiful stretches of often unpopulated white sand. A half-mile walk past artichoke fields offers views onto a harbor seal preserve.
This dramatic, secludedbeach in a protected cove is a choice spot for surfers and windsurfers.

website: Forest of Nisene Marks State Park
place: Forest of Nisene Marks State Park
desc: This beautiful park offers 10,000 acres of semi-rugged wilderness, rising from sea level to coastal mountains at 2,600 feet, with more than 30 miles of trails. A former logging site, the park contains remnants of ...more

This gorgeous preserve in the west valley foothills offers hikers, cyclists and equestrians forested hillsides, open hayfields and Hunters Point, a 900-foot hilltop with breathtaking views of the Santa Clara Valley.
